discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
From Cisco book : LLQ provides strict priority queueing for CBWFQ, reducing jitter in voice conversations in other queues are dequeued. Configured by the priority command, LLQ enables use of a single, strict priority queue within CBWFQ at the class level, allowing you to direct traffic belonging to a class to the CBWFQ strict priority queue.
This is C, Priority is the keyword that configures LLQ https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios/12_2sb/12_2sba/feature/guide/sballqpc.html

questions.question_text: Which characteristic of distributed class-based weighted fair queueing addresses jitter prevention?

discussion.content: It could be between A and D the correct answer. B and C are incorrect, CBWFQ alonely can not offer priority queue, it must be LLQ.

comments.content:
Sorry A and C but based on Cisco DCO :
Class-Based Weighted Fair Queuing (CBWFQ): Provides class bandwidth guarantee
for user-defined traffic classes. It provides flow-based WFQ support for nonuserdefined
traffic classes.

discussion.content: Actually, I don't know I think B and C but generally B

Selected Answer: C
Voting so it shows, it's C based on this information https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/qos_conmgt/configuration/15-mt/qos-conmgt-15-mt-book/qos-conmgt-oview.html

Selected Answer: C
I think it is C. 
Because why would we allow (users) to define classes ?. 
QOS classes should be defined by Admins not users
A and D kinda say the same thing. I am going to go with D, just because it uses the word "define", which is all over Cisco documentation.

Selected Answer: D
i think it's D.
 https://www.cisco.com/en/US/docs/ios/12_0t/12_0t5/feature/guide/cbwfq.html

 Feature Overview

Class-based weighted fair queueing (CBWFQ) extends the standard WFQ functionality to provide support for user-defined traffic classes. For CBWFQ, you define traffic classes based on match criteria including protocols, access control lists (ACLs), and input interfaces. Packets satisfying the match criteria for a class constitute the traffic for that class. A queue is reserved for each class, and traffic belonging to a class is directed to the queue for that class.

Selected Answer: A
Answer A by wording i found

Class-Based Weighted Fair Queueing (CBWFQ)
provides weighted fair queuing based on defined classes with no strict priority queue
available for real-time traffic. 
CBWFQ allows <a user> (you) to define traffic classes and then assign characteristics to that class. 

https://www.ccexpert.us/qos-implementing/lower-priority-classes-use-cbwfq.html

Selected Answer: C
C. It minimizes jitter by implementing a priority queue for voice traffic.

comments.content: welll B and C are the same .. so if C is correct why no B ?
B says it avoids, C says it minimizes. You can't avoid jitter, you can only minimize. B is the only one in the list that I mentally threw out all together.

choices.B: It uses a priority queue for voice traffic to avoid jitter.
choices.C: It minimizes jitter by implementing a priority queue for voice traffic.
choices.D: It provides additional granularity by allowing a user to define custom classes.
choices.A: It provides additional granularity by allowing a user to create classes.

questions.question_text:
An administrator with ID123456789 is receiving complaints of pixilation, smearing, and pulsing of video calls between two offices that are connected by a WAN.
Assuming that QoS is implemented on the WAN connection, which classification is used to mark the video traffic, according to the Cisco QoS baseline?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
ECN is correct - https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/quality-of-service-qos/qos-packet-marking/10103-dscpvalues.html#:~:text=the%20same%20way.-,Differentiated%20Services%20Code%20Point,Congestion%20Notification%20(ECN)%20bits.

Selected Answer: B
A currently unused 2-bit (CU) field is reserved for explicit congestion notification (ECN).

questions.question_text: What are the last two bits of a DS field in DiffServe Byte used for?

choices.B: Voice traffic must be marked to DSCP AF41.
choices.E: Average one-way jitter is greater than 50 ms.
choices.A: Loss must be no more than 1 percent.
choices.C: One-way latency must be no more than 200 ms.
choices.D: Voice traffic must be marked to DSCP EF.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD
correct A and D
